questions.text: The total amount of urine passed by a patient in 24-h is found to be 350 ml. What is the status of the patient based on the above finding?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oliguria- Pathological Oliguria refers to a 24-h urine output <400 mL and Oliguria is never normal, since at least 400 mL of maximally concentrated urine must be produced to excrete the obligate daily osmolar load.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Anuria is the complete absence of urine formation (<100 mL). Option: C. Non-oliguria refers to urine output >400 mL/d in patients with acute or chronic azotemia. Option: D. 400 ml- 3000 ml per 24 h.

Extraedge:

Complete anuria early in the course of AKI is uncommon except in the following situations Complete urinary tract obstruction, Renal artery occlusion, Overwhelming septic shock, Severe ischemia (often with cortical necrosis), or Severe proliferative glomerulonephritis or vasculitis

questions.text: Microscopic finding of urinary sediment of a patient shows the following. What is the most probable constituent of crystal?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Calcium oxalate dihydrate Calcium oxalate dihydrate crystals are bipyramidal/envelope shaped.

Highyeild:

Medications Associated with Nephrolithiasis and Nephrocalcinosis Calcium Stone Formation Loop diuretics Vitamin D Corticosteroids Calcium supplements Antacids (calcium and noncalcium antacids) Theophylline Acetazolamide* Amphotericin* Topiramate Uric Acid Stone Formation Salicylates Probenecid Allopurinol (usually associated with xanthine stones) Melamine (in contaminated infant formula and milk products Medications that May Precipitate into Stones Triamterene |Acyclovir (if infused rapidly intravenously) Indinavir | Nelfinavir

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Cystine crystals are hexagonal. Option: C. They are yellow or brown rhomboid-shaped seen singly or in rosettes. They can also be in the form of prism, plates, and sheaves Option: D. They are yellowish in the form of silky needles or sheaves.

Extraedge:

Crystals in urine are usually associated with kidney stones. Crystals form in the urine depending upon a variety of factors including: The degree of concentration of constituent molecules The urine pH The presence of inhibitors of crystallization Uric acid and xanthine stones are radiolucent and will not be visible on plain films. Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones:- Struvite/Staghorn stones - Radiopaque, seen in alkaline urine, Rectangular/coffin lid appearance urinary stones, associated with urea-splitting organisms(.Ein th image-triple phosphate) Cystine stones - Radiopaque, seen in acidic urine, Hexagonal shaped, Very hard stones(G in the image) Uric acid crystals - Radiolucent, seen in acidic urine, seen in varying shapes(rhomboids or parallelograms)(In the picture) Calcium oxalate mono/dihydrate stones - Radiopaque, seen in acidic urine, Dumbbell shaped/envelope shaped, Most common type of renal calculi.(B in the image) Amoxycillin crystal ( I in image )resembling a branch of broom brush calcium phosphate crystal (D in image) star-like brushite. Correct identification of urine crystals requires knowledge of crystal morphology, Urine pH, and appearance under polarizing light.

questions.text: Presence of which of the following in the urine is diagnostic of glomerular injury:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

20% dysmorphic RBCs Glomerular hematuria : It should be suspected in the presence of i. Dysmorphic (crenated) urinary erythrocytes ii. Presence of RBC casts iii. Concomitant proteinuria (> 1 gm/day) Non-glomerular hematuria : It is characterized by the presence of i. Isomorphic urinary erythrocytes ii. Absence of RBC casts iii. No significant proteinuria or proteinuria <1gm/day.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency with a history of fever for 3 days and decreased urine output since yesterday. He says that he has passed only 300ml of urine in the last 24 hrs. Serum creatinine is found to be 4.2mg/dl. USG shows normal kidney size. Which of the following is an indication of urgent dialysis in a case of AKI?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Indications for Urgent Dialysis:- 1. Potassium persistently high 2. Symptoms of uremia (persistent nausea, vomiting, encephalopathy, bleeding, etc) 3. Acidosis (pH <7.1) 4. Many nephrologists initiate dialysis empirically when BUN exceeds 100 mg/dl 5. Pulmonary edema not responding to diuresis 6 . Pericarditis 7. High catabolic state with rapidly progressive renal failure. 8. In CKD when eGFR < 10ml/min/1.73m2

questions.text: A 50-year-old female,k/c/o CKD stage 5 on maintenance HD thrice a week complains of a creepy-crawly sensation over her legs. It is like a deep ache which worsens in the night and she is unable to sleep due to this. It is temporarily relieved by movement, stretching, or massage. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gabapentin Restless legs syndrome (RLS) is a neurological disorder characterized by an irresistible urge to move one's body to stop uncomfortable or odd sensations. It most commonly affects the legs. Gabapentin is used in the treatment. Agonists of D2/D3 receptors like pramipexole or ropinirole are also effective, but about 25% develop, augmentation ie worsening symptoms -Underlying cause has to be treated.

Extraedge:

Drugs that can be associated with symptoms of restless legs syndrome (RLS) Caffeine Antidepressants (except bupropion) Antipsychotics Dopamine-blocking antiemetics (eg, metoclopramide) Centrally-acting antihistamines

questions.text: What is the major component of the fluid used in the procedure shown below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dextrose Peritoneal Dialysis:- Continuous ambulatory Peritoneal Dialysis (CAPD/APD) a. In this, a permanent catheter is inserted into the peritoneum via a subcutaneous tunnel. b. Up to 2 liters of dialysate (rich in dextrose) is introduced and exchanged up to 5 times a day. c. Peritoneal membrane itself acts like a filtration membrane. The major difference between the dialysate used for peritoneal rather than hemodialysis is that the hypertonicity of peritoneal dialysis solutions drives solute and fluid removal, whereas solute removal in hemodialysis depends on concentration gradients, and fluid removal requires transmembrane pressure Complications of Peritoneal Dialysis: Peritonitis (usually Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, or coliforms) Catheter blockage Weight gain and poor diabetic control (dialysate fluid has high sugar content) Pleural effusion.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Platelet count is reduced HSP:- The diagnosis is based on the combination of the symptoms, as very few other diseases cause the same symptoms together. Blood tests may show elevated creatinine and urea levels (in kidney involvement), raised IgA levels (in about 50%), and raised C-reactive protein (CRP) or erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) results; none are specific for Henoch–Schönlein purpura. The platelet count may be raised, and distinguishes it from diseases where low platelets are the cause of the purpura, such as idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura.

Extraedge:

The tetrad of HSP is: Palpable purpura in patients with neither thrombocytopenia nor coagulopathy Arthritis/arthralgia Abdominal pain Kidney disease
